Janice, isn't it true though that women in abusive relationships (mental or physical) tend to remain inexplicably attached for longer than they should even though it's obvious to the rest of us that breaking away is the only obvious alternative?

I know you write with sincerity, and I often enjoy reading your comments, but being smart and well-educated doesn't necessarily result in mitigating the misery that women feel when they are in self-destructive relationships. Nor does it always result in them making the right decision to leave. When we are "in love", one of the first casualties is often our intellect and/or common sense. Regrettably.

I suppose it's easy to know what the right course of action to take is when on the outside looking in. She of course doesn't have that luxury.

I have sympathy for Huma, but of course all any of us can do is engage in conjecture when we try to make sense of her predicament. I think she deserves the benefit of the doubt, especially after that vicious and ignorant demagogue Michele Bachmann basically accused her of being a terrorist sympathizer.

Emma doesn't seem aware that she is contradicting herself: if rent control is defunct now, how would free market rents change anything?

My own view is that rent control is not quite defunct, but serves as an unnecessary friction in the market. The actual market mechanisms which work around rent control -- bribes, waiting, networking like crazy -- are all deadweight losses to the economy; every one of them is a genuine cost of living wherever one ends up.

Thus it seems to me that the abolition of the pretense of rent control would result in a reduction of overall costs, and thus probably in a reduction of many Manhattan occupancy costs.

-dlj.

Yup, same here. Poor and, frankly, even many middle class people are going to be pushed outward just as in lots of other major cities, where they will take up residence as a kind of second-class. New York will have a luxury core, and no more of its old soul.

Sorry, it just seems very obvious to me that all free market rents in NYC would make the city way less affordable than it is now. Rent control and stabilization are not especially fair, but they do enable economic diversity in NYC and especially in the East Village where I live.

Rent control is effectively defunct, since rent controlled apartments are not available to anyone new and haven't been for some time. We're going to find out real soon how much diversity we'll have without either, thanks to strong landlord lobbies and Citizens United.

I've lived in NYC all my life, but the city I know and love has left me. I will probably leave whenI can no longer afford to live here.

Anon,

Of course I am painting with a broad brush, as are you and every other person on this chat!

Your experience and that of your friend seem completely reasonable, from this limited example, it would appear that both of you are engaged parents who can read the writing on the wall with their kids. That said, my point is that attending EVERY game/performance is not necessarily a bad thing (after shuttling the kid to EVERY practice mind you), I have just observed that it creates an unintended consequence in messaging to that kid. Someone on this chat actually said that going to all of this stuff is how you show your kid that you love them. Really? I thought the providing of emotional, financial, physical, and psychosocial security was my love demo. JV soccer? Not so much.

Can you really say in all honesty that any mom wouldn't like to blow of just one game in a twenty game season to grab a mani/pedi while that kid is playing a basketball game with a riveting 19 to 16 final score?

In my very humble opinion, sometimes we send messages to our kids that they are they center of the universe, when they would do fine without our watchful and encouraging eyes. Yes, sometimes your kids will "uninvite" you, which makes the call easier. But I would also encourage moms and dads to not judge their parenting by the amount of time they are THERE, but by their ability to give that child both roots and wings.

But really, if you want to go to every game, knock yourself out.

What sort of discipline would you prefer over scolding and "time out"?  Screaming?  Physical violence?

I understand that there are degrees of quality in daycare, sure and also that in decent one, kids will be "fine." Kids come out of war torn countries and refugee camps and can be "fine." But again, I ask people to be honest with themselves. Do you really think an infant, new to the world, has an equal experience with a paid caregiver, however kindly, but often one of a few being cared for, who's doing it for a job, as compared to being with the person who is utterly in love with them, high on oxytocin and delights in their every new move? You're deluding yourselves. Unless of course, the mom is just not really that into it. I think that's something I have trouble coming to terms with. Or it's just excruciatingly sad to me to think that someone would have to turn those feelings off because they *have* to go to work...

Mouse - four year olds aren't generally articulate enough to express their anger in another way. One of our jobs as parents is to teach them more civilized ways to express their anger and frustration - not by punishing them when they come out with that, but by helping them find better ways. My response, when my kids have said, "I hate you" for such things, has been to say "I know you're really angry, but you still can't [do whatever it is that they want to do]." over time, they have come to say, "I'M REALLY ANGRY!" instead of "I hate you!" Little kids lack both impulse control and the ability to formulate more subtle responses to frustration.

Mouse, I've had similar experiences - my kids don't always jump up without being nudged, but I definitely nudge them to clear their places (and their grandmother's, because she can't stand easily - and because she's their grandmother), and I do the same. I am stunned at how often parents not only don't ask their kids to do the same, but actively discourage mine from doing it.
Children understand a lot more than we think they do. Just because they can't produce language at a certain level doesn't mean they don't understand it at that level.

@Rose: It's not rare to find a donor who's willing to be known in the US. You can just ask the clinic or donor agency for donors who are willing. If you seek treatment in the UK, she'll be known; anonymity is against the law there. In contrast, if you go to the Czech Republic or Spain, non-anonymity is against the law... so it depends where you go. Also, if you have a young enough relative or friend to donate, that eliminates anonymity and also is much less expensive.

But quite apart from that, adopting from any foreign country typically means you'll be raising a child who will never know *100%* of its genetic roots (though there are exceptions). And adopting from the US can mean the child won't know 50% of its genetic roots, since sometimes the bio-dad is unknown to the birth mother or she refuses to reveal his identity.

Long story short, one of the side effects of infertility is that if you get to raise a child at all, that child usually will never know at least one of its genetic parents. At least with egg donation (or sperm donation), if you use your husband's sperm (or your own egg), the child not only knows but is raised by one of its genetic parents--unlike adopted children. Also, thanks to sites like the Donor Sibling Registry, they may well be able to connect with genetic half-siblings even if they never connect with the donor herself (or himself).

When I was a kid growing up in Toronto, I was allowed to walk to school alone at 6 (3 blocks away), walk the dog alone during daylight hours at 6, to take the subway by myself at 9 and to babysit at the ripe old age of 12 (CPR certification in hand).

When our daughter was 8, my husband and I lived in Ottawa, in a very safe, pretty posh neighbourhood called the Glebe. Allowing Kate to walk the dog to a nearby farmers' market (maybe four blocks away), in broad daylight, on a sunny Sunday morning resulted in a visit from the local police. Really. A neighbour was so worried about Kate's welfare that she reported us to CPS. I'm all for making sure a child is safe and well taken care of but, man, this was just OTT.

It wasn't just a one-off either -- a lovely Swiss couple with three tween girls who lived around the corner laughed off the first visit from the police (similar circumstances; their son *gasp* walked the dog alone in broad daylight in our very safe neighbourhood), got a second visit from the police a few weeks later (same thing!) and stopped allowing their kiddos to wander around unaccompanied.
